awd_abstract_narration:
This planning proposal looks to enable the engagement of academic researchers and coastal community stakeholders around Alaska. The community  stakeholders include tribal entities, community member harvesters, and mariculture farmers. The team will use the planning process to begin discussions around workforce development and diversity activities to be included in the future EPSCoR Track-1 Glaciers to Gulf (G2G) proposal.  The G2G proposal will address aspects related to: Terrestrial Export, Marine Resources, and Human Dimensions.  The topics are aligned with Alaska's Science and Technology Plan.  The primary desired outcomes from the planning grant activities include: 1) a team science collaboration plan outlining best practices for stakeholder engagement and co-production of research; 2) an assessment of existing strengths and weaknesses with respect to the research themes and jurisdictional capacity (SWOT analysis); 3) an evaluation of the existing gaps in jurisdictional expertise and knowledge (gap analysis); and 4) a draft of a logic model to ensure success of G2G.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this planning grant was to enable academic researchers and coastal community collaborators from around the Gulf of Alaska to engage in a meaningful way in preparation for submission of a new Track 1 proposal. This planning process was used to begin discussions around research needs, workforce development, and diversity activities that will be included in the Track 1 submission. The funding from this planning grant specifically enabled face-to-face meetings between the research team and community collaborators, and supported limited staff time to assist the team during the meetings and in organizing the meetings.

Using this grant, academic researchers from all three universities in the University of Alaska (UA) system traveled to the communities of Sitka, Juneau, Haines, Klukwan, Hoonah, Valdez, Homer, Halibut Cove, Peterson Bay, and Seldovia. During these meetings UA researchers met with various types of community members including tribal members, agency managers, and community researchers, harvesters, and mariculture farmers to discuss needed research and/or workforce development activities. These community visits are essential for true co-production of research ideas and the development of the Track 1 proposal.

Also, during this planning grant, the UA researcher team traveled to single locations to have face-to-face meetings to discuss outcomes of community meetings and pivoting of research topics and approaches for the next Track 1 submission based on NSF and community partner input. Because of the distances between the various UA campuses, it is difficult for faculty in one location to have face-to-face meetings with faculty at other locations, especially those who are stationed in a remote location. While we continue to have zoom meetings, these in-person meetings are necessary for making progress and keeping faculty engaged.


Last Modified: 07/01/2023
Modified by: Brenda H Konar
